util
Class ArgumentChecker

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--util.ArgumentChecker
public class ArgumentChecker
extends java.lang.Object

This class provides several static methods for checking, manipulating, and accessing command line arguments. It allows you to check if a valid argument set was given to your program with one simple call to a static method. It also provides a single method to check for the presence of a switch, or for retrieving the value associated with a switch.

The main functionality of this class is based around the concept of a description String. A description String is a simple, custom regular expression which describes a legal command line for your program. A switch is indicated with a '-'. A value is any String that does not start with a '-', '[', ']', or '|', or the usual reserved characters for your shell or command line interpreter.

Switches and arguments which are optional are enclosed in square brackets. When a choice exists, the '|' character indicates an OR situation. An example of a description String would be:
"-version | -help | -s server [ -p port | -i interval ]"

The above description String means the following. You could invoke the program and give it ONLY the argument "-version". Or, you could invoke it and give it ONLY the argument "-help". Or, you could invoke it and give it a "-s", then a server name. If you do this, you can include other parameters after the "-s server" part, if you want. You could give it a "-p" and some string representing a port number, or you could give it a "-i" and some String representing an interval. You could NOT give it anything after the "-version" String, or the "-help" String, if you used either of those. Note that all tokens in the description MUST be seperated by spaces.

You use it in your program as follows: 

   public static void main (String[] args) {
     ...
     String usage = " -version | -help | server [ port ]";
     if (!ArgumentChecker.isValid(usage, args)) {
       System.err.println("usage: ProgramName " + usage);
       return;
     }
     // if we get here, then the arguments are legal.

This version has undergone a complete rewrite. If you find any bugs, please let me know at 013639s@dragon.acadiau.ca.

Method Detail

isValid

public static boolean isValid(java.lang.String description,
                              java.lang.String[] args)
This method checks if the given arguments legally satisfy the given description. The description in this version is very simple. It is merely a String describing legal command line argument sets in a generic format. If a parameter in the description starts with a '-', then the entire item must be matched exactly in the arguments. If a parameter in the description starts with a '[', then it is an optional argument. An example would be to pass the array {"-s" "schedule.dat"} and the description "[ -s datafile ] [ -d dayOfWeek ]". This should return true.

Nesting is supported in versions 1.4 and above. This means that a description String such as "[ -s datafile [ -o outputfile ] ] -d day" would be perfectly legal. The level of nesting is restricted only by Java or the amount of memory in your machine.

Parameters:
args - the command line arguments.
description - a simple regular expression describing legal arguments.
Returns:
true of the given arguments satisfy the description, false otherwise.

minNumber

public static int minNumber(java.lang.String description)
Returns the minimum number of allowed arguments based on the given description.
Parameters:
description - the String describing the allowable argument string as described above in the comment for isValid().
Returns:
the minimum number of arguments which may be supplied based on the given description. Returns -1 if an error occurs.

maxNumber

public static int maxNumber(java.lang.String description)
Returns the maximum number of allowed arguments based on the given description.
Parameters:
description - the String describing the allowable argument string as described above in the comment for isValid().
Returns:
the maximum number of arguments which may be supplied based on the given description. Returns -1 if an error occurs.

paramAtSwitch

public static java.lang.String paramAtSwitch(java.lang.String switchID,
                                             java.lang.String[] args)
This method is used to get the value associated with a switch. It supports only very simply value association; one switch to one value. It is used as follows: 
    args = { "-s", "sourceFile", "-o", "outFile" }
    paramAtSwitch("-s", args)
would return "sourceFile". 
    paramAtSwitch("-l", args)
would return null.
Parameters:
switchID - the String representing the switch to look for.
args - the array of Strings making up the argument list.
Returns:
the value associated with the named switch, if the named switch exists in the args array. If the switch is not found, null is returned.

switchFound

public static boolean switchFound(java.lang.String switchID,
                                  java.lang.String[] args)
This method is used to determine if a particular argument is found in the argument array. It is intended to detect whether or not a switch is in the arg array, but it doesn't check for a '-'. It will return true if switchID is exactly equal to any String in the argument array.
Parameters:
switchID - the String to look for.
args - the array to look for the switch in.
Returns:
true if switchID is exactly equal to any String in args.
